headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The question I have is the phasing in of the manufacturing costs throughout the year. Could you just give us some guidance as to, is this the number that you disclosed in your flow chart, how should we be thinking about it throughout the year and if it ca
componenttext: The question I have is the phasing in of the manufacturing costs throughout the year. Could you just give us some guidance as to, is this the number that you disclosed in your flow chart, how should we be thinking about it throughout the year and if it can actually become a drag by the end of the year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, manufacturing costs are material, labor, overheard, warranty, and we expect all of those to be favorable for the full year. They were actually pretty favorable in the first quarter. You know, I think for material costs, it’s probably a little bit
componenttext:
Again, manufacturing costs are material, labor, overheard, warranty, and we expect all of those to be favorable for the full year. They were actually pretty favorable in the first quarter. You know, I think for material costs, it’s probably a little bit easier in the first quarter because we were coming out of, the first quarter of ’09 was coming off of the higher cost level coming out of ’08. 
So I would say probably for material costs, with commodity prices up, and I think the comps will get increasingly difficult, so I think material costs will get harder as we go through the year.
I think in terms of labor and overhead, we’ve got a lot of programs in place. I think we’re doing a pretty good job. Now the first quarter of last year, that’s when we started the ramp down, but I mean, I think it will probably be favorable as we go through the year. I think further implementation of Cat production system. We’ve got higher volumes, and all of that ought to be pretty good for manufacturing costs.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So by Q4 we’d still be better than nothing. I know it’s hard to forecast the future, but in general, that’s the direction I should be thinking of.
componenttext: So by Q4 we’d still be better than nothing. I know it’s hard to forecast the future, but in general, that’s the direction I should be thinking of.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that’s correct. Again, though I think the comps get harder as you go through the year on material costs, so that’s one where I would guess the gap would be shrinking.With that, we’ll let Jim wrap up.
componenttext:
I think that’s correct. Again, though I think the comps get harder as you go through the year on material costs, so that’s one where I would guess the gap would be shrinking.
With that, we’ll let Jim wrap up.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Mike, and my thanks to all of you. Let me just start by saying I’ve enjoyed the opportunity over the last six and a half years to work with the analyst community. You’ve been very understanding. We’ve had good working rapport I would say and
componenttext:
Thanks Mike, and my thanks to all of you. Let me just start by saying I’ve enjoyed the opportunity over the last six and a half years to work with the analyst community. You’ve been very understanding. We’ve had good working rapport I would say and I appreciate the work that you all do.
Secondly of course, the greatest honor for me has been playing quarterback for what I think is one of the finer companies on the global stage; great people the world over and in terms of accomplishments, the people side of the equation, what we’ve done on the safety and engagement side, I think bodes very well for the future of our company. It’s just indicative of the kind of very positive change that we’ve made on a continuous and steady basis.
We’re very much focused on managing through the cycle. I think we were challenged certainly to get the pull through we would have liked with explosive growth from ’03 through ’08. I think we demonstrated a lot of capability, maybe surprising some of you, on our ability to manage a very troublesome and horrific recession in ’09.
I think it was one of our finest hours. We showed a lot of nimbleness in taking cost out in a hurry and did achieve what we consider a hat trick of sustaining profitability, sustaining our credit rating and our dividend. And, I think we continued to invest in key capacity bottlenecks and in research and engineering that bode very well for our future.
We’re very much focused on delivering results for long term shareholders, and sometimes I know that doesn’t square with the image of CEO’s that are focused on just quarterly pennies, but we’re very much focused on the long term shareholder.
I think we have our company exceptionally well positioned for growth on a global scale. I can’t tell you, I was honored with Doug’s opening comments, but I think the transition that we planned has been well laid out. It’s going exceptionally well. I’m confident you’re going to hear a strategy roll out in August which shows you exactly how the team is going to take our company to another level going forward for the next five or ten years.
So again, it’s been an exciting time. I again appreciate all the work and rapport that we’ve had and good look on the forecast for the coming year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: With that, we’re at the end of our hour. Thank you very much and we’ll be talking to you over the next quarter.
componenttext: With that, we’re at the end of our hour. Thank you very much and we’ll be talking to you over the next quarter.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Caterpillar First Quarter 2010 Earnings Results. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mr. Mike DeWalt, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, the floor is y
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Caterpillar First Quarter 2010 Earnings Results. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mr. Mike DeWalt, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, the floor is yours.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, and good morning, everyone and welcome to Caterpillar's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. I'm Mike DeWalt, the Director of Investor Relations. And I'm pleased to have our Chairman and CEO, Jim Owens; our Vice Chairman and Chairm
componenttext:
Thank you very much, and good morning, everyone and welcome to Caterpillar's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. I'm Mike DeWalt, the Director of Investor Relations. And I'm pleased to have our Chairman and CEO, Jim Owens; our Vice Chairman and Chairman Elect, Doug Oberhelman; and our CFO, Dave Burritt, with me on the call today. 
This call is copyrighted by Caterpillar Inc., and any use, recording or transmission of any portion of the call without the expressed written consent of Caterpillar is strictly prohibited. If you'd like a copy of today's call transcript, you can go to the SEC Filings area of the Investor section of our cat.com website or to the SEC's website, where it will be furnished as a form 8-K today. In addition, what we'll be discussing today is forward-looking and involves risks, uncertainties and assumptions that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking information. A discussion of some of the factors that individually or in the aggregate we believe could make actual results differ materially from our projections can be found in our cautionary statements under Item 1A, Risk Factors, of our Form 10-K, filed with the SEC on February 19, 2010, and also on our forward-looking statement's language contained in today's release.
Okay, earlier this morning, we reported results for the first quarter and we updated our outlook for the full year of 2010. And to start this morning, I'll quickly summarize the quarter and updated outlook. Then we'll take your questions. 
Okay, let's start with the quarter and what a difference a year makes. In the first quarter last year, we were seeing rapidly declining demand, order cancellations, turmoil in credit markets and declining economies across much of the world. At Caterpillar, we were busy cutting production, costs, employment and working capital. Our major focus was on three goals, maintaining profitability, holding the dividend and maintaining our midday credit rating, and we were successful at all three.
This year's first quarter saw a very different picture. Capital markets are in much better shape than last year. Demand for our products is rising, and we're seeing it in most geographic regions, although it's much more robust in the developing countries of Asia, Latin America, Africa/Middle East and the CIS.
We're also seeing a significant pickup in mining globally. In fact, we've already filled our available 2010 production slots for some of our large truck models and are taking orders for 2011. Demand for aftermarket service parts in our Machinery and Engine businesses is very strong and gained steam as we moved through the quarter. And this is usually a good indicator of how much work is getting done in the field, and the strength we've seen is encouraging.
While working with our suppliers and within our own factories to ramp up production and, in some cases, to accelerate planned capacity additions in terms of employment, what we are able to absorb, a portion of the production improvement with the existing workforce by winding down the rolling plant shutdowns that we used last year to manage production declines. However, we're also selectively adding to employment to support increasing demand. We're seeing employment increases in our factories in Asia, in Latin America, where the demand improvement is the strongest. And also in key U.S. facilities, they are seeing strong export demand. And employees in those factories certainly understand the importance of free trade.
I think the contrast between last year and this year can be summed up by saying last year, we were rapidly ramping down and faced a very negative economic climate. This year, we're rapidly ramping up and are seeing much better prospects for the world economy.
Sales in revenues in the first quarter were $8.2 billion, and that was down about $1 billion from the first quarter of last year. Now, given my positive comments about the economic environment, you may be asking why our sales and revenues were lower than the first quarter last year when demand is improving and we're ramping up production. Well, there were two main reasons. First, we ended 2008 with a strong order book for mining products and large engines. And while we saw cancellations and very few new orders, we did continue to produce and ship mining products, large engines and turbines at relatively good levels throughout the first quarter of 2009. The second reason is that it does take some time to ramp up, and not just in our factories. Our suppliers are seeing, in many cases, dramatically higher demand from us. We've increased production schedules throughout the quarter, and March was our best month for sales and revenues since the end of 2008. 
One other point about sales, and that is throughout 2009, we talked a lot about the impact of fewer inventory changes and the very negative impact that had on our full year 2009 sales as dealers shut inventory. This year, we're expecting relatively flat dealer inventory, and for the most part, that's what happened in the first quarter. Overall, dealers held new Machine inventories about flat, but took Engine inventories down about $200 million.
While the midpoint of our outlook reflects relatively flat dealer inventories in 2010, in some regions, inventories are becoming lean. And the higher we are this year in our outlook range, the more likely it is that, collectively, dealers may add some to their inventories later in the year. 
Okay, let's turn to the first quarter profit. Profit in the quarter was $0.36 a share, and during the quarter we recorded a $90 million after-tax charge related to Medicare subsidy tax changes in the recently signed U.S. healthcare legislation. Excluding that charge, profit was $0.50 a share. That compares with the first quarter of 2009 when we had a loss of $0.19 a share, including redundancy costs of $558 million. Excluding the impact of redundancy, we earned a profit of $0.39 a share in the first quarter last year. Now, again, that's $0.50 a share in the first quarter this year, excluding the Medicare charge, and $0.39 a share in the first quarter last year, excluding redundancy.
Okay, just a few key points about the quarter.  Profit was higher despite lower sales volume and a negative product mix. Manufacturing costs were favorable, $566 million. And included in that, labor and overhead costs, warranty and material costs were all favorable. SG&A and R&D costs were close to being neutral, despite added costs for incentive compensation and pension expense.
Our Machinery line of business was profitable for the first time since the third quarter of 2008, and engine operating profit, as a percent of sales, improved sequentially from the fourth quarter of 2009. Cash flow was a positive and our Machinery and Engines debt-to-capital ratio improved from year-end 2009. 
All in all, it was a good quarter. Demand and order rates have picked up. We're ramping up production. Efficiency is improving. Costs were down and the balance sheet continues to improve.
Okay.  That was a quick look at the quarter. Now let's turn to the outlook. This morning, we raised guidance for sales and revenues and for profit. Our original outlook reflected sales and revenues up 10% to 25% from 2009. And in dollars, that was a range of $35.6  billion to $40.5 billion, with the midpoint of about $38 billion. The revised outlook we've provided this morning has a top line range of $38 billion to $42 billion with the midpoint at $40 billion. In terms of profit, the original outlook expected $2.50 a share at the midpoint of the sales and revenues range. And our revised outlook this morning reflects a range of $2.50 to $3.25 per share, with the midpoint of $2.88. And a point of clarification, that outlook does include the negative impact of the first quarter tax charge related to the U.S. healthcare legislation. In other words, our profit expectation for the year would have been higher if the bill had not been enacted.
Now, there are four main reasons for the improvement in our outlook this morning. First, while our original outlook for 2010 did expect growth in developing countries, it's now looking even stronger. Engine sales, particularly for gas turbines, are looking better than we expected. Sales of aftermarket parts, which are integral to and included in our Machinery and Engine businesses are growing faster than expected. And, finally, mining is increasing more than in our original outlook.
Now, in terms of costs in the outlook, in general, what we said in our original outlook looks to be about on track, and some key elements include: Favorable material costs for the full year; favorable manufacturing, labor and overhead costs driven by improving factory efficiency; SG&A costs should be up slightly, excluding short-term incentive pay. And as we said in our original outlook, we do expect higher R&D expense. And as a reminder, pension costs are up as well and included in manufacturing, SG&A and the R&D lines. 
Also, one other point with profit improving, we do expect increased short-term incentive pay. And that's linked to improving financial results and is, as a result, highly aligned with shareholder interest. Okay, that's the outlook. 
In summary, the first quarter was a very good start for the year. We're seeing positive increases in demand, our machine production is increasing and we raised the outlook for 2010. Just one more comment before we move on to the Q&A section, and that is we're going to hold our annual analyst meeting this year in New York City on August 19 in the afternoon. So mark your calendars. We'll provide you more details on that over the next couple of weeks.  And with that, we're ready to take your questions.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And Mike, maybe before we do that, I'd like to interject here a little bit. This is Doug Oberhelman speaking. As you all know, I'll become CEO in about two months' time, and I thought given that this is Jim Owens' last quarterly call, I would mention a fe
componenttext: And Mike, maybe before we do that, I'd like to interject here a little bit. This is Doug Oberhelman speaking. As you all know, I'll become CEO in about two months' time, and I thought given that this is Jim Owens' last quarterly call, I would mention a few key statistics of Jim's time in office here and what's happened during what will no doubt be one of the most interesting runs as CEO in our history where sales mushroomed and then sales tanked, and I'll get into that in just a little bit. Jim has done a-- we all think here, a wonderful job for our company, and let me tell you some of that. Jim became our CEO on February 1, 2004. That seems like many lifetimes ago, Jim, but it went fast and here we are in 2010 already.  That's six years and 24 quarters, for the record. 2003 earnings per share before Jim came in as CEO were $1.56 a share. And I know as I look back at some of these statistics, I had forgotten a lot of this history. Of course, we peaked at $5.66 a share in 2008, which was a record of any time in our history. 2003 sales were $23 billion, and I can remember so well a couple of studies we did at that time, wondering how we were going to ever break above $20 billion, where we had been stuck for six or seven years or so at that number. And sure enough, in 2008, we ballooned up to $51 billion and exceeded our – Jim's strategic goal of $50 billion by 2010. Unfortunately, in 2009, we cut that back by almost 40%. And now, as you can see from our outlook for 2010, we're back up to 40%. This is really – gets interesting. During this period of time, when Jim was our CEO and Chairman, our stock has risen almost 80%.  Even with the ups and downs of 2009, a tremendously successful run as CEO and Chairman. When Jim took over, our quarterly dividend was $18.5, today it's $0.42, that's 125% increase. And I will tell you that Jim was the main cheerleader, main arm twister of our board and main driver of maintaining that dividend last year when everybody else was looking to cut around our industry in so many other companies. He was forthright in his determination, that we were going to make it through it, we were going to be profitable in '09, which we were; maintained our dividend and our cash flow, which we did, and it paid off very well for shareholders. Employment's up about 25,000 during this period of time. It certainly was up more than that. But in the end, we're still up over where he started. And I think what he'll really be remembered for, and all of you on the – as shareholders and that sell side, probably don't know a lot of this, but the internal things we've changed on Vision 2020, which was his strategy plan that we are working on revising now again. It brought us the growth in China and emerging markets. It brought us the Cat production system. It brought us improvements in quality we're seeing. It brought us sufficiencies in our factories. Set us up for the next few years, which we'll really see these things pay off. And we're all pretty excited about that. We've set us up for the Tier 4, Stage IIIB in Europe, emissions regulations, brought us the acquisition of Progress Rail, which has turned out to be a real winner and one we're extremely happy of. And I know Jim is very proud of his attendance and membership in the Economic Advisory Council under President Obama. Another final cap on this, market cap when Jim took over was about $27 billion. Today, I notice it's right at $45 billion. And just a great run with this giant roller coaster in the middle, but he got us through all that. So, Jim, with that, and this will be the first of many -- not the first, but the first of many farewells between now and November 1. But congratulations to you.  And these statistics you can hold up with anybody, anywhere in the industry, any time.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Doug. I'm speechless.  But it is true, those are all facts.
componenttext: Well, thank you, Doug. I'm speechless.  But it is true, those are all facts.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, we're ready for Q&A. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay, we're ready for Q&A. Thank you.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from Alexander Langdon.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is coming from Alexander Langdon.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Alex, this is Mike. Just as a reminder, we did raise sales guidance.  Today, at the midpoint, it went up about $2 billion. The midpoint of our guidance is $40 billion. I think we provide a range around that because there are uncertainties in terms of what
componenttext: Alex, this is Mike. Just as a reminder, we did raise sales guidance.  Today, at the midpoint, it went up about $2 billion. The midpoint of our guidance is $40 billion. I think we provide a range around that because there are uncertainties in terms of what's going forward. And not everything in the year is positive. I mean, there are some parts of the business that – Engines, for example, we see as being flat this year, not a big increase, at least at the midpoint. I think if you were to look at new machine production and look at the percentages around that, that would look better than the total overall. I think you would find dealer sales, the users are up more than what total sales are, again, partly because engines are flat and the service-related businesses that were in the high 40s in terms of a percent of our total sales and revenues are much more stable than the Machine and Engine business. So the bottom line to that is I think you're just looking at new machine sales, percentage-wise, that's where more of the increase is, new machine sales.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe just one -- a touch of color to that, too, I mean, as you know, the recovery in Machine sales, particularly in the United States, Europe and Japan, the tradition we'll always see in these countries, it's pretty anemic at this point. So we have very
componenttext: Maybe just one -- a touch of color to that, too, I mean, as you know, the recovery in Machine sales, particularly in the United States, Europe and Japan, the tradition we'll always see in these countries, it's pretty anemic at this point. So we have very robust growth occurring across the Asia/Pacific theater,  Latin America and selected parts of Europe, Africa/Middle East, but very anemic growth in the OECD world, which is a substantial percentage of the total industry, globally.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Mark Koznarek.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Mark Koznarek.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Cleveland Research. I'd like to ask the question around the Turbine business because 90 days ago, we thought that would be down pretty significantly. I guess at the meeting that you hosted out there last year, people got the sense it was going to be down
componenttext: Cleveland Research. I'd like to ask the question around the Turbine business because 90 days ago, we thought that would be down pretty significantly. I guess at the meeting that you hosted out there last year, people got the sense it was going to be down double-digits. And the guidance now seems to be flat. And first of all, I'm wondering if those are reasonable suppositions in terms of the change? And then if you can talk about where the demand improvement is coming from.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the second part of it as being relatively flat, that's a pretty good supposition. The piece before that about it being down significantly, we'd never used those words. We said it would be off of the peaks of '08 and '09. We never really did give a p
componenttext: Well, the second part of it as being relatively flat, that's a pretty good supposition. The piece before that about it being down significantly, we'd never used those words. We said it would be off of the peaks of '08 and '09. We never really did give a percentage range, but I would have never called it significant. And the improvement that we've seen is primarily for Solar than in Latin America. Both oil and gas and electric power.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just add a little bit to that. Mark, you're right. We were definitely more bearish last August about Solar's 2010 than we are today. Several things have happened. Mike alluded to most of those. I would say the biggest surprise we had was – that's
componenttext: Let me just add a little bit to that. Mark, you're right. We were definitely more bearish last August about Solar's 2010 than we are today. Several things have happened. Mike alluded to most of those. I would say the biggest surprise we had was – that's new since we talked to you last, was a couple of very big orders in Latin America that are coming through in 2010 that we did not expect to be -- to surface. They did, and that really helped out the year in 2010. And then, secondly, the phenomena around shale gas in the U.S., which is growing everywhere, and you can read about that constantly. But that's driving lots of the new investment in drilling, and that's full compression, of course, into the mainline gas lines in the United States. So those two things have been a – one, in the case of Latin America, a very positive outcome we did not know about at that time. And shale gas has held up a lot more briskly than we thought. So those two are the broader things that I would answer that with.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on this Turbine business, what roughly is that manufacturing cycle time? Are these two- and a three-quarter kind of production schedules, or could we potentially even see further upward revision? If orders come in, could they still impact
componenttext: Just a follow-up on this Turbine business, what roughly is that manufacturing cycle time? Are these two- and a three-quarter kind of production schedules, or could we potentially even see further upward revision? If orders come in, could they still impact revenues later this year?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say on the short end, Solar would probably be six. It depends a lot, Mark, on the product. In my last discussions with them, I think on the short end it's about a six-month lead time. And on the longer end, a year or more – a year-ish for some o
componenttext: I would say on the short end, Solar would probably be six. It depends a lot, Mark, on the product. In my last discussions with them, I think on the short end it's about a six-month lead time. And on the longer end, a year or more – a year-ish for some of the big, more complicated stuff.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, that would be for new packages.  For their customer services side of the business, which is very substantial for them, they can react in a shorter time frame.
componenttext: Yeah, that would be for new packages.  For their customer services side of the business, which is very substantial for them, they can react in a shorter time frame.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Seth Weber.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Seth Weber.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can just -- you mentioned a couple of times how the mix was a negative drag on margins. I'm wondering if you could, if it's possible, just to quantify that a little bit more? Give us some  more detail, whether that was more on the Mac
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can just -- you mentioned a couple of times how the mix was a negative drag on margins. I'm wondering if you could, if it's possible, just to quantify that a little bit more? Give us some  more detail, whether that was more on the Machinery or the Engine side? And then, as we look forward, is it possible to frame that with the guidance, if you see the revenue numbers coming in more towards the top end of the guidance?  Would that be more of a headwind or less of a headwind?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, generally speaking, the sales mix -- I'll give you just a couple of points around the first quarter, and then we can kind of talk about the year. If you think back to last year, we had really high Engine margins in the first quarter, relatively weak
componenttext: Well, generally speaking, the sales mix -- I'll give you just a couple of points around the first quarter, and then we can kind of talk about the year. If you think back to last year, we had really high Engine margins in the first quarter, relatively weak Machine margins. And if you look at the sales change quarter-over-quarter, Machines held up pretty well. Most of the decline was in Engines. So in the first quarter, a bigger decline in higher-margin Engine business than Machines. Then if you get within Machines and within Engines, you'd see even more of it. We were producing large engines, turbines, mining products out of the backlog to a higher degree, let's say, in the first quarter of a year ago. So we had a pretty good Engine mix, we had a pretty good Machine mix. And Engines were relatively stronger than Machines. And all of that kind of turned around here in the first quarter. So those are the negatives. The positives, there were some positives -- on balance, it was negative for the quarter. There were a few positives, though. We talked a little bit ago about aftermarket.  That has seen good improvement, and that helped to offset some of the declines. As you look out through the full year, partly because of the inventory declines, the dealer inventory declines last year, we're going to have probably quite a rebound from much of the smaller products, because it has more of an impact from the dealer inventory changes. So our small BCP product production and sales on that is just going to be up substantially this year, and a lot of that is from dealer inventory impacts. So I think as we progress through the year and the Machine sales are up, we'll continue to see this negative mix throughout the year. And it's a -- we didn't quantify it in the release separately, but it's fairly significant.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so just to clarify, if you hit the top end of your revenue guidance, you think that would be a function of selling more of the lower margin product?
componenttext: Okay, so just to clarify, if you hit the top end of your revenue guidance, you think that would be a function of selling more of the lower margin product?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in all things, there's a range for all sorts of the product. In other words, there's a range for mining, there's a range for oil and gas. Jim made a point a bit ago about Solar service business, for example, being able to react. So I think t
componenttext: Well, I think in all things, there's a range for all sorts of the product. In other words, there's a range for mining, there's a range for oil and gas. Jim made a point a bit ago about Solar service business, for example, being able to react. So I think there's plus and minus potential for probably each part of the business. So it depends which part of the business drove the score to the top end.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Ann Duignan.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Ann Duignan.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: JPMorgan. My question is around seasonality. Maybe you could help us understand, given that you're talking about ramping up production from here on out, versus we'd normally model Q2 being stronger and then Q3 weaker. How should we think about seasonality
componenttext: JPMorgan. My question is around seasonality. Maybe you could help us understand, given that you're talking about ramping up production from here on out, versus we'd normally model Q2 being stronger and then Q3 weaker. How should we think about seasonality, particularly Machines, Mike, as we go through 2010, because it's not a normal year?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Seasonality is much more difficult to play in when you're at kind of an inflection point, I think, like we are now, where we've moved from things getting worse to flattening out to moving up. So I think the way I would think about it is production will pr
componenttext: Seasonality is much more difficult to play in when you're at kind of an inflection point, I think, like we are now, where we've moved from things getting worse to flattening out to moving up. So I think the way I would think about it is production will probably ramp as we go through the year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then just a quick follow-up.  Since you raised the midpoint of your revenues, how comfortable are you still that input costs will not now be a net negative?
componenttext: Okay, and then just a quick follow-up.  Since you raised the midpoint of your revenues, how comfortable are you still that input costs will not now be a net negative?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: You mean material costs?
componenttext: You mean material costs?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, material costs were actually favorable in the first quarter and, in a part of that, $566 million of manufacturing costs that we reported. So we're off to a pretty good start. But in all things, the outlook is a forecast. And, certainly, things could
componenttext: Well, material costs were actually favorable in the first quarter and, in a part of that, $566 million of manufacturing costs that we reported. So we're off to a pretty good start. But in all things, the outlook is a forecast. And, certainly, things could change based on where commodity prices are, our discussions with suppliers, the cost-reduction actions that we've enacted, the purchasing forward that we've done. I think we're reasonably comfortable that we'll have favorable material costs this year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from David Raso.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from David Raso.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: ISI.  Just thinking about the implied incremental margins for the rest of the year. Year-over-year incrementals are implying 18%. And even if I want to add back $400 million of higher R&D in the rest of the year in the sense of comps, say, around 250, it'
componenttext: ISI.  Just thinking about the implied incremental margins for the rest of the year. Year-over-year incrementals are implying 18%. And even if I want to add back $400 million of higher R&D in the rest of the year in the sense of comps, say, around 250, it's only implying 26% incremental. And I appreciate the mix, but I know we've discussed the times – I mean, incrementals are different than absolute. I know BCP is not a good margin business on an absolute level. But year-over-year, we spoke of BCP could get to break even this summer. That's a big incremental in that business. So what am I missing, why, even with the R&D and the incentive comp, 26% incremental margins? I mean, Machine revenues are going to be up 55% year-over-year the rest of the year as per guidance. Is there something I'm missing about the incremental margin?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: First, a couple of things, David.  Our variable margin rate would be in the sort of mid-30s normally. So with that as a starting point, we do have negative mix, like we've talked about, going forward. We do have a little bit higher R&D costs. When you hav
componenttext: First, a couple of things, David.  Our variable margin rate would be in the sort of mid-30s normally. So with that as a starting point, we do have negative mix, like we've talked about, going forward. We do have a little bit higher R&D costs. When you have big increases in volume, that does drive a little bit of period costs in the factory. Incentive compensation is higher, that's related to higher profit. So I think those are all things that would take our variable margin rate and kind of mitigate it. And, again, I think it's R&D, I think it's incentive comp, I think it's product mix. And that's what would take our kind of mid-30s variable margin rate down into the mid-20s.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: But, again, the mid-20s, I had to back the R&D in the short term. I mean, if you want to go all in, you're saying the normal mid-30s, so it's going to be cut in half to 18. And I'm just trying to be clear, is there something unique? Because I would have f
componenttext: But, again, the mid-20s, I had to back the R&D in the short term. I mean, if you want to go all in, you're saying the normal mid-30s, so it's going to be cut in half to 18. And I'm just trying to be clear, is there something unique? Because I would have figured, initially, price versus costs. You're still guiding in a way that price versus costs maybe isn't quite as robust as three months ago, but it's not an incremental negative [indiscernible].

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike,  I know it's hard for me to guess what's in your model. But I would suspect probably that maybe you're not factoring in enough for sales mix. I don't know.
componenttext: Mike,  I know it's hard for me to guess what's in your model. But I would suspect probably that maybe you're not factoring in enough for sales mix. I don't know.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And real quick, what implies for '11, if dealer inventory's flat?  And I know Cat with a Lane Strategy is trying to keep the dealer inventory tight. I'm just curious, what is management's view of a comfortable level for the dealer inventory? Because whate
componenttext: And real quick, what implies for '11, if dealer inventory's flat?  And I know Cat with a Lane Strategy is trying to keep the dealer inventory tight. I'm just curious, what is management's view of a comfortable level for the dealer inventory? Because whatever you want to assume about retail growth in '11, the dealer did take out $3.3 billion of inventory in '09. And it's now hard to handicap it, but what is the thought, either be you, Mike or Doug or Jim  on –  in '11, would it be logical that you're going to get half of the $3.3 billion back? I mean, what are you comfortable with and, obviously, it depends on how effective the Lane Strategy is, but what's the comfort level?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, you've got it, David. And I would say at this stage, it's going to be hard to judge '11 for lots of reasons. But we're just over halfway through implementation of our Lane Strategy right now, which – we've got a long ways to go with that, where it
componenttext: Yeah, you've got it, David. And I would say at this stage, it's going to be hard to judge '11 for lots of reasons. But we're just over halfway through implementation of our Lane Strategy right now, which – we've got a long ways to go with that, where it is working, the dealers love it, we love it, and it's really going to pay off. But how that sorts out with the ramp up here the rest of 2010 and how fast we can get that fully implemented is going to be part of the answer for 2011, as is the economic environment in 2011. But we've got a view that between rentals, between dealer inventory and between our finished goods inventory in Lane 1, that entire -- the aggregate of that mix is what we're aiming for to improve on any prior cycle we've had. So it's a bit – even if we wanted to comment about 2011, which we don't, we would not be in a position just yet to talk about the full impact of the Lane Strategy. But I think it's coming. And I think by the time we see you  in August we'll have a lot better, I think, idea of where that's going to end up. But we're still in the growth stage, in the formative stage of that as we go. And many of you have heard that through your dealer surveys as well.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: But is it fair to say, flat inventory in '11 versus '10?
componenttext: But is it fair to say, flat inventory in '11 versus '10?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: David, this is Mike. I think we'll pass on talking about 2011 and we need to move on to the next question.
componenttext: David, this is Mike. I think we'll pass on talking about 2011 and we need to move on to the next question.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Henry Kirn.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Henry Kirn.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It's UBS. Could you talk a little bit about how demand by end-market applications will shift in 2010 versus the last few years?
componenttext: It's UBS. Could you talk a little bit about how demand by end-market applications will shift in 2010 versus the last few years?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, definitely – if we take Machines, definitely, we're seeing increasing end-user demand in mining. Actually, if you look worldwide, things actually look slightly positive for residential.  Although North America is certainly down, infrastructure spe
componenttext: Well, definitely – if we take Machines, definitely, we're seeing increasing end-user demand in mining. Actually, if you look worldwide, things actually look slightly positive for residential.  Although North America is certainly down, infrastructure spending around the world looks pretty good. I think, generally speaking, if you look worldwide, again, driven by the emerging market countries, I think most all of the end markets look from slightly to moderately positive. But mining is, from a Machine standpoint, is definitely looking best. I think from Marine, things are looking up right now in oil and gas.  We talked about Solar a little bit ago, and Doug touched on the shale gas. Electric power is looking a little bit better. Marine still weak, and the MaK business is probably likely to decline.  So Marine is probably a weaker one. Actually, in the first quarter, we had good sales from industrial. That piece of it, I think, turns a little quicker. So that's looking more positive. But I think maybe with the exception of Big Marine, I think most of the end markets are looking a little bit better.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is from Eli Lustgarten.
componenttext: Our next question today is from Eli Lustgarten.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Longbow Securities. Can you talk a little bit more about the cost side of it?  If material costs aren't going up this year, how far out are you hedged this year? It's my understanding, you basically hedged for almost the entire year in mostly major steel
componenttext: Longbow Securities. Can you talk a little bit more about the cost side of it?  If material costs aren't going up this year, how far out are you hedged this year? It's my understanding, you basically hedged for almost the entire year in mostly major steel and costs. And as part of it, with admissions coming next year, you have high material costs, you're going to have to face a one point or another in emissions. What's the probability of seeing some sort of pre-buy, both in the Engine and particularly in the machinery side as we get towards the end of the year because of the potential for higher prices next year?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll start out with a first part of material costs. We don't actually do a lot of hedging per se. There's a little bit, but not a lot. What we have done a little bit more of this year is do some pre-buys. I guess you might call that a form of hedging. But
componenttext: I'll start out with a first part of material costs. We don't actually do a lot of hedging per se. There's a little bit, but not a lot. What we have done a little bit more of this year is do some pre-buys. I guess you might call that a form of hedging. But we've gone out to some of our suppliers and done a little bit of a pre-buying, both to kind of lock in some supply and some price. And I think those mostly just go out through a couple of quarters. So it's not massively extensive. I think the biggest positive for us on material costs this year, I think commodity costs will be up. But we've done a lot of work to drive cost reduction, design and sourcing-related cost reduction. And our view is that's going to likely offset the commodity related increases this year and keep us slightly favorable.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about Tier 4 a little bit, Eli, and you'll be seeing our strategy on Tier 4 here roll out in the next few weeks, in a month or two in terms of what we intend to do with our models that we offer and our pricing strategy. As you know, the off-ro
componenttext: Let me talk about Tier 4 a little bit, Eli, and you'll be seeing our strategy on Tier 4 here roll out in the next few weeks, in a month or two in terms of what we intend to do with our models that we offer and our pricing strategy. As you know, the off-road business really has never seen a pre-buy phenomena like the on-road business has. Depending on what the strength of the economy – when all of us in the industry announced 2011 strategies, I would expect some pressure from customers on some pre-buy. But, again, it's going to be spotty and dependent. You've got to remember, Tier 4 and IIIB only applies to really Western Europe, Japan and America, and then it's a phase-in. The rest of the world has nothing to do with Tier 4 at the moment, which should be 2/3 of the business, if not, a little more. But I would expect in some models, in some zones, geographically, we would see some heightened order activity midyear, third quarter, after they see how we're all going to come at this for 2011. As it rolls on out through '12 and '13, as more and more of the horsepower ratings and ranges come in,.  And depending on what happens with the January 11 early model adapters, you could see some of that. And I think we would expect something around that. But it's really difficult to predict at the moment, with so much uncertainty in exactly the place where Tier 4 and IIIB is going to occur, Western Europe and the U.S. And it might not be that material, Eli, because just your capacity in the fourth quarter, given how fast things are ramping up.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from ^^Joel Hit.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from ^^Joel Hit.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in the first quarter, Machine inventory was about flat. So in the first quarter a year ago, I think Machine inventory declined about $300 million. So we said this year would be flat. And for Machines, that's what happened actually in the first quart
componenttext: Well, in the first quarter, Machine inventory was about flat. So in the first quarter a year ago, I think Machine inventory declined about $300 million. So we said this year would be flat. And for Machines, that's what happened actually in the first quarter. Dealers actually took a couple hundred million out for Engines.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Right.  Plus production is essentially, for the most part, sales.
componenttext: Right.  Plus production is essentially, for the most part, sales.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from ^^Jamie Cook.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from ^^Jamie Cook.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Jamie, I'll start that question out and then I'll let Jim and Doug chime in as they want to. I think basically, with the Lane Strategy, you always have to look at this in pieces. It's not as simple as just what are lead times, because it really depends up
componenttext: Jamie, I'll start that question out and then I'll let Jim and Doug chime in as they want to. I think basically, with the Lane Strategy, you always have to look at this in pieces. It's not as simple as just what are lead times, because it really depends upon what channel they come out of. With Lane 1, for example, our target is about a 10-day lead time. And except for a couple of products that are coming out of Japan, and we actually underestimated demand -- except for those couple of products, generally speaking, that's about where we're at. So delivery time for roughly 24% of Machine sales that came out of Lane in March, lead times are very, very short. Now, for products that the dealers place on the factory and don't get out of Lane 1 we've moved, in terms of quoted delivery times, from sort of 11 to 12 weeks to around 15 weeks. So it has moved out. And I think that's really a function of, again, being in an inflection point, where we are in process of moving production up to a higher level. I would point out, though, as a part of that, we are giving preferential treatment to dealer orders that have a customer attached. So if there's a customer involved, those orders generally get shipped three or four weeks earlier than an inventory order if a dealer's ordering to add to his inventory. So I think in the scheme of things, delivery times are going out, but really aren't too bad.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Jim Owens. Just a brief comment. Captive goods are notoriously difficult to forecast. Three to six months ago, most of you, all of our dealers, many of our customers were very pessimistic about the global economy. And I don't think they saw the V-shaped r
componenttext: Jim Owens. Just a brief comment. Captive goods are notoriously difficult to forecast. Three to six months ago, most of you, all of our dealers, many of our customers were very pessimistic about the global economy. And I don't think they saw the V-shaped recovery, particularly in a lot of commodity sectors and emerging markets that was unfolding even at that time. So we've had a very sharp bounce back in enthusiasm here. And, quite frankly, our economics group was well ahead of most marketing groups, as well as even customers in forecasting the upturn and the strength of commodity markets. So as early as October last year, we've been out working with suppliers, not only our direct suppliers but our second tier suppliers, and helping them understand this inventory cycle and how it's going to impact their sales. I think we're more ahead of it, if you will, certainly, than we were coming into the '04 cycle. And our ability to ramp up now is really a function of how fast we can bring this supply chain along. Our ability -- we're kind of capacitized for $35 billion or so in top line sales and revenue. But we've got to bring our supply base up to get to that kind of level, and that's going to take some time. And we're working that issue very hard. Again, we had a roadshow in October, helping to get them prepared for this eventuality. We weren't certain it would happen, but we thought there was a high probability. So I think we're out in front of this to a reasonable extent, compared to where we were back in '04.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Ted Grace.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Ted Grace.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010

componenttext: It's Ted Grace from Avondale Partners. I have a quick question on Integrated Services. In the press release, we could see that it was about 47% of 1Q revenue. And then if you could give us any color on some of the other big parts, logistics and Progress Rail would be terrific.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010

componenttext: I'm going from memory here, Ted, but I think last year was around 40% in terms of Integrated Services, so this year is a little bit above that. So, in other words, last year, we did 9.2% and 40% of that would have been Integrated Service related.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: And then any specific color on Machines versus Engines, then logistics versus Progress Rail? We could already see what happened with financial services?
componenttext: And then any specific color on Machines versus Engines, then logistics versus Progress Rail? We could already see what happened with financial services?

componenttextpreview: The only place where it actually made any specific comments is around the aftermarket piece of that, and that is definitely improving. Again, the rest of the -- in general, in the Integrated Services businesses, you don't go up and down as dramatically as
componenttext: The only place where it actually made any specific comments is around the aftermarket piece of that, and that is definitely improving. Again, the rest of the -- in general, in the Integrated Services businesses, you don't go up and down as dramatically as certainly new Machines that new Engines sales, so I'll sort of leave it at that. We've never really broken them out and shown them separately.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add a couple of things. The manufacturing business and our Progress Rail element have performed well in 2009 as we expected them to do. And they're enjoying a bit of an uptick as well, and not dissimilar to the rest. So it's kind of across th
componenttext: I would just add a couple of things. The manufacturing business and our Progress Rail element have performed well in 2009 as we expected them to do. And they're enjoying a bit of an uptick as well, and not dissimilar to the rest. So it's kind of across the board, but the big driver was those aftermarket parts, as we've said many times, and that's important to us.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Andrew Casey.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Andrew Casey.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The answer to the first question is if you look at Solar, just a couple of observations. One, we said full year, [indiscernible] it should be close to last year. But last year, they had a really big first quarter and second quarter. And already in the fir
componenttext: The answer to the first question is if you look at Solar, just a couple of observations. One, we said full year, [indiscernible] it should be close to last year. But last year, they had a really big first quarter and second quarter. And already in the first quarter, their deliveries were below the first quarter of a year ago. So the last three quarters ought to be better. They had a really big second quarter, so I would suspect that year-over-year, they'll probably see a bigger increase in the second half of the year. I'm sorry, what was the second part of your question?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: But having said that, Mike, we are still cautionary beyond -- in terms of where we're going to be in 2010, we were surprised by a couple of big orders we did not anticipate. We'll see how it goes after that. So I'd say that's a fair comment on Mike's, but
componenttext: But having said that, Mike, we are still cautionary beyond -- in terms of where we're going to be in 2010, we were surprised by a couple of big orders we did not anticipate. We'll see how it goes after that. So I'd say that's a fair comment on Mike's, but we'd go no further.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: On the capacity issue, that's a rough number. Again, we actually did over $51 billion at '08 prices in '08 with only one quarter of Cat in Japan in the number. So, basically, the 55 is an observation based off where we were in 2008.
componenttext: On the capacity issue, that's a rough number. Again, we actually did over $51 billion at '08 prices in '08 with only one quarter of Cat in Japan in the number. So, basically, the 55 is an observation based off where we were in 2008.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: No. That would be, let's say, where we're at today. Typical price would definitely go up.
componenttext: No. That would be, let's say, where we're at today. Typical price would definitely go up.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Barry Bannister.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Barry Bannister.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: It's Barry Bannister from Stifel Nicolaus. I was looking at an Engineering News Record article on February 22, and it said that Cat construction equipment prices will rise about 12% over the next four years as the company rolls out Tier 4. And then it goe
componenttext: It's Barry Bannister from Stifel Nicolaus. I was looking at an Engineering News Record article on February 22, and it said that Cat construction equipment prices will rise about 12% over the next four years as the company rolls out Tier 4. And then it goes on to say that about a third of the increase or 4%, would start in 2010, said Cat officials at the Peoria headquarters. Pricing in the quarter was 2%. Are you planning on trying to do 4% this year or was the article out of context? And does 12% over several years sound about right?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: The 12% was really starting in 2011 not 2010, when Tier 4 starts. And that's not necessarily an overall Machine number. We'll adjust in those places where you're going to get Tier 4. For the product that goes to emerging markets that's not Tier 4,  that c
componenttext: The 12% was really starting in 2011 not 2010, when Tier 4 starts. And that's not necessarily an overall Machine number. We'll adjust in those places where you're going to get Tier 4. For the product that goes to emerging markets that's not Tier 4,  that certainly wouldn't apply. The point of the article, Barry, was that kind of, on average, over kind of the Tier 4 implementation, we're seeing a cost increase and we felt the need to get about 4% for Tier 4. And the thought was that we would try to do it uniformly over a few years rather than just one lump sum at introduction, say, in 2011. So it really wasn't so much a 2010 comment.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me come back to this a little bit, Barry, in terms of Tier 4 phase-in. Tier 4 is not a big bang by any stretch. In fact, there's some fairly narrow horsepower band ratings that was in beginning January 1, '11. That's the very first pricing activity th
componenttext: Let me come back to this a little bit, Barry, in terms of Tier 4 phase-in. Tier 4 is not a big bang by any stretch. In fact, there's some fairly narrow horsepower band ratings that was in beginning January 1, '11. That's the very first pricing activity that we would take for Tier 4 emissions. And then over the next four years, culminating with the big high horsepower stuff in locomotives and barges, Tier 4 is done. But nothing happens in '10. And then it's really a building wave in '11, '12, '13, '14 and '15.  As those new products come in, there's lots of ways to use the regulations to the industry's benefit in there as well. So we'll be talking a lot more about that probably in August, and you'll see as we go what our strategy will be as the year rolls on.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we have time for one or two more. And then Jim will wrap up.
componenttext: I think we have time for one or two more. And then Jim will wrap up.

componenttext: Yeah, I think what we talked about is increases of up to 12% on Tier 4 products and then we're going to phase it in.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Remember, Tier 4 is Machines, Engines, Locomotives, every single product off road we make, across our 300 product families and beyond. So it's a very broad statement that applies to a lot of things. The specifics will be – we'll be dealing with the spec
componenttext: Remember, Tier 4 is Machines, Engines, Locomotives, every single product off road we make, across our 300 product families and beyond. So it's a very broad statement that applies to a lot of things. The specifics will be – we'll be dealing with the specifics as we introduce these products going forward. It's a very -- almost technical review of pricing, as well as competitive environment at that time.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll talk about that more when it happens in 2011. But, remember, all the sales don't phase in the first year, either, so.
componenttext: We'll talk about that more when it happens in 2011. But, remember, all the sales don't phase in the first year, either, so.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010

componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Andrew Obin.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Bank of America Merrill Lynch. The question I have is on phasing in over the manufacturing costs throughout the year. Could you just give us some guidance as to -- this is the number you disclosed in your waterfall chart. How should we be thinking about i
componenttext: Bank of America Merrill Lynch. The question I have is on phasing in over the manufacturing costs throughout the year. Could you just give us some guidance as to -- this is the number you disclosed in your waterfall chart. How should we be thinking about it throughout the year, and if it can actually become a drag by the end of the year?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well,  again, manufacturing costs are material, labor and overhead, warranty. And we expect all of those to be favorable for the full year. They were actually pretty favorable in the first quarter. I think for material costs, it's probably a little bit ea
componenttext: Well,  again, manufacturing costs are material, labor and overhead, warranty. And we expect all of those to be favorable for the full year. They were actually pretty favorable in the first quarter. I think for material costs, it's probably a little bit easier in the first quarter because we were coming out of -- first quarter of '09, it was coming off of maybe a higher cost level, coming out of '08. So I would say probably for material costs, with commodity prices is up, and I think the comps will get increasingly difficult. So I think material costs will get harder as we go through the year. I think in terms of labor and overhead, we've got a lot of programs in place. I think we're doing a pretty good job. Now, the first quarter of last year, we did -- that's when we started the ramp down. I think it will probably be favorable as we go through the year. I think we have further implementation of Cat protection systems. We've got higher volumes.  And all that ought to be pretty good for manufacturing costs.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: So by Q4, it would still be better than nothing, right?
componenttext: So by Q4, it would still be better than nothing, right?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again...
componenttext: Well, again...

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I understand it's hard to forecast the future, but, in general, that's the direction I should be thinking of?
componenttext: I understand it's hard to forecast the future, but, in general, that's the direction I should be thinking of?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's correct. Again, though, I think the comps get harder as you go through the year on material costs. So that's one where I would guess that the gap would be shrinking. Okay, with that, we'll let Jim wrap up.
componenttext: I think that's correct. Again, though, I think the comps get harder as you go through the year on material costs. So that's one where I would guess that the gap would be shrinking. Okay, with that, we'll let Jim wrap up.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and thanks to all of you. Let me just start by saying I've enjoyed the opportunity over the last 6.5 years to work with the analyst community. You've been very understanding. We've had good working rapport, I would say. And I appreciate the
componenttext: Thanks, Mike, and thanks to all of you. Let me just start by saying I've enjoyed the opportunity over the last 6.5 years to work with the analyst community. You've been very understanding. We've had good working rapport, I would say. And I appreciate the work that you all do. Secondly, of course, the greatest honor for me has been for me to play quarterback for what I think is one of the finer companies in the global stage, great people the world over. And in terms of accomplishments, the people side of the equation, what we've done on the safety and engagement side, I think bodes very well for the future of our company. It's just indicative of the kind of very positive changes that we've made on a continuous and steady basis. We're very much focused on managing through the cycle. I think we were challenged, certainly, to get [indiscernible] closer than we would have liked with explosive growth from '03 through '08. I think we demonstrated a lot of capability – maybe surprising some of you – on our ability to manage a very troublesome and horrific recession in '09. I think it was one of our finest hours. We showed a lot of nimbleness in taking costs out in a hurry, and did achieve what we considered the hat trick of sustaining profitability, sustaining our credit rating and our dividend. And I think we continued to invest in key capacity bottlenecks and in research and engineering that bode very well for our future. We're very much focused on delivering results for long-term shareholders. And sometimes I know that doesn't square with the image of CEOs that are focused on just quarterly pennies. But we're very much focused on the long-term shareholder. I think we have our company exceptionally well positioned for growth on a global scale. I can't tell you – I was honored with Doug's opening comments, but I think the transition that we've planned has been well laid out. It's going exceptionally well. I'm confident you're going to hear a strategy rolled out in August which shows you exactly how the team's going to take our company to another level going forward for the next 5 to 10 years. So, again, it's been an exciting time. I again appreciate all the work and rapport we've had. And good luck on these forecasts for the coming year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-26-2010
componenttextpreview: With that, we're at the end of our hour. Thank you very much. And I will be talking to you over the next quarter.
componenttext: With that, we're at the end of our hour. Thank you very much. And I will be talking to you over the next quarter.
