componenttext: Barry, this is Ed. In terms of the move from defined benefit with defined contribution, that's going to play out over a number of years as we phase out of it. I wouldn't look at it, as if you would, a savings on a year-over-year basis, as you do your numbers.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, I reread the transcript from the August analysts meeting and Cat Financial was never mentioned, eventhough it was about 18% of the last dozen years profit and about 16% year-to-date. Does Cat Financial play a role in your a multi-year pla
componenttext: And then lastly, I reread the transcript from the August analysts meeting and Cat Financial was never mentioned, eventhough it was about 18% of the last dozen years profit and about 16% year-to-date. Does Cat Financial play a role in your a multi-year plan?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cat Finance plays a huge role on our multi-year plans. I mean, if you think back, Barry, to 2009, which was the all-time stress test in terms of financial markets, and you've seen from numbers Cat Finance have performed very well through that downturn. It
componenttext: Cat Finance plays a huge role on our multi-year plans. I mean, if you think back, Barry, to 2009, which was the all-time stress test in terms of financial markets, and you've seen from numbers Cat Finance have performed very well through that downturn. It's tied very much into our business model, being able to go to customers and provide them not only great products but great services. Cat Finance continues to not only grow in what historically has been the developed parts of the world, but is playing a key role in the developing markets as well such as China, Russia and other parts of the world that are growing. So Cat Finance remains a central part of our overall strategy.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is there a risk, before I get off, that you're expanding and becoming the largest lender in places like China, yet you've never had a downturn to deal with and that the finance companies going to overreach?
componenttext: And is there a risk, before I get off, that you're expanding and becoming the largest lender in places like China, yet you've never had a downturn to deal with and that the finance companies going to overreach?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, think it's our job to manage that risk and if there was ever going to be a stress test to overreach or not, it would have been '09. And I think, if you look at how well we performed during that period of time, we managed it well. We're taking the very
componenttext: No, think it's our job to manage that risk and if there was ever going to be a stress test to overreach or not, it would have been '09. And I think, if you look at how well we performed during that period of time, we managed it well. We're taking the very same principles that we applied in other parts of the world, as we've expanded with the Cat Finance company and used them there. I mean, we're financing product that we know, we're working with dealers that we partnered with Ion [[ph]] that we understand, we know how to redistribute, we understand the residual values. It's a business model but we've exercised around the world and we've stayed very close to it.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Alexander Blanton.[Ingalls & Snyder]
componenttext:
Our next question today is coming from Alexander Blanton.
[Ingalls & Snyder]

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd like to just ask a question about your Caterpillar Production System. It clearly is getting great results because if you look at the gross margin line and look at the incremental gross margin year-over-year, with the LIFO in last year, it was 36%, whi
componenttext: I'd like to just ask a question about your Caterpillar Production System. It clearly is getting great results because if you look at the gross margin line and look at the incremental gross margin year-over-year, with the LIFO in last year, it was 36%, which is in the middle of your historic range of 30% to 40%. But if you take out the LIFO gain last year, it was at 39% incremental margin year-over-year on the gross margin line, and that's with a very negative mix change that you mentioned. So clearly, there are great things going on in the manufacturing, could you just elaborate on what some of those are?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mike. I mean, we only have 30 minutes left for this call so I'll try to be brief with that. But Cat Production System is pervasive throughout the factory. It's all about building the schedule, for example, and our ability to actually build to
componenttext: Yes, this is Mike. I mean, we only have 30 minutes left for this call so I'll try to be brief with that. But Cat Production System is pervasive throughout the factory. It's all about building the schedule, for example, and our ability to actually build to our schedule has just improved dramatically. I saw the statistics over the last couple of days where our performance has gone -- of the amount that we've missed, the performance is going down by about 3/4 in terms of missing builds. So working with the supply chain, all the discipline around standard work has helped a lot in meeting production schedules and that helps efficiency. Lane strategy has helped as well. We're producing higher percentage of what we're doing, our more standard products which helps efficiency. So I think it's not just one thing, it's a combination of all the work on the supply chain, the standard work in the factory, Lane strategy, all kind of working together, to simplify. I would also be remiss if I didn't say it help the increase in volume helps as well.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Those are interesting metrics because it's like inventory reduction. In order to get an inventory reduction or in order to get a better improvement on deliveries or cycle time, you mentioned, you have to reduce the costs, correct? I mean, you haven't real
componenttext: Those are interesting metrics because it's like inventory reduction. In order to get an inventory reduction or in order to get a better improvement on deliveries or cycle time, you mentioned, you have to reduce the costs, correct? I mean, you haven't really told us where those costs reductions are. You just told us about the results which is good.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just let me add this from a little different take, Oberhelman here. If you look at our forecast for next year approaching $50 billion, coming off the bottom of $31 billion 2 years ago, and we've done that increase over, call it a two-year period arguably,
componenttext: Just let me add this from a little different take, Oberhelman here. If you look at our forecast for next year approaching $50 billion, coming off the bottom of $31 billion 2 years ago, and we've done that increase over, call it a two-year period arguably, but ought to, the last time we did that it was four years more or less. And we're doing it this time with better quality, better pull through, almost every metric inside our factory. So that's the kind of the big picture that I look at in terms of are we doing it better than we ever have in the past, we certainly are. And then you see things like you've mentioned there, Alex, in some of the numbers with the gross margin etc. And we also like the internal metrics around committed ship dates around our quality numbers and so on. So that is coming our way and the CPS dividend is starting to pay and be evident.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And did these improved manufacturing results have to do with your decision to build factories in the United States now instead of abroad? Was that a factor and may you be able to get your costs down to the point where you can be create a job here rather t
componenttext: And did these improved manufacturing results have to do with your decision to build factories in the United States now instead of abroad? Was that a factor and may you be able to get your costs down to the point where you can be create a job here rather than abroad, is that correct?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alex, this is Ed. Our manufacturing strategy is really driven by serving on the high-volume product in kind of those three industry zones like we've always done, historically. We're seeing great traction on CPS in the U.S. We're seeing great traction in C
componenttext: Alex, this is Ed. Our manufacturing strategy is really driven by serving on the high-volume product in kind of those three industry zones like we've always done, historically. We're seeing great traction on CPS in the U.S. We're seeing great traction in CPS in Europe. Great traction on CPS on Asia. So our manufacturing strategy is really more driven by serving local markets with local manufacturing.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Ann Duignan. [JP Morgan]
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Ann Duignan. [JP Morgan]

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about -- you are very careful about laying out some of the headwinds that you're are facing going into 2011. Could you talk about any tailwinds that might be out there going into 2011, for example, mix, or one region being stro
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about -- you are very careful about laying out some of the headwinds that you're are facing going into 2011. Could you talk about any tailwinds that might be out there going into 2011, for example, mix, or one region being stronger or Engines are recovering. Could you just give us any examples of where there might be a tailwind?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll just talk about some of the things that we've already talked about. I mean, we didn't put in this mornings release that we do expect some, although modest to our price increase next year. The sales volume is pretty good. Mix, though, I kind of t
componenttext: Yes, I'll just talk about some of the things that we've already talked about. I mean, we didn't put in this mornings release that we do expect some, although modest to our price increase next year. The sales volume is pretty good. Mix, though, I kind of talked about a little earlier, the growth in sales has been more centered around machines than Engines, so I think from a mix standpoint, you have to say that does not look very positive for next year. The flipside of that, though, is machine margins have been improving a lot. They're well below where we were in the last cycle, and so there's, I think, there's certainly a lot more room for improvement there. Beyond that and we've not talked yet about efficiency or cost reduction, material costs, that's not because we're trying to send the negative signal, we're just still in the process of working all those resource plans.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So volume is a wonderful thing really, is that the key take away?
componenttext: So volume is a wonderful thing really, is that the key take away?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's probably a good take away. And I think the other one, and as Mike mentioned in his opening comments is just what's happened in the U.S. we've been through an extended downturn. Fleets are aging, and rental fleets are down versus historical numbers, a
componenttext: It's probably a good take away. And I think the other one, and as Mike mentioned in his opening comments is just what's happened in the U.S. we've been through an extended downturn. Fleets are aging, and rental fleets are down versus historical numbers, and that's another thing as Mike mentioned earlier, that should bode as well going forward.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you just talk a little bit about how much of your revenues to dealers, particularly on the rental side are or even end users, are coming with tradings and, therefore, you would know maybe you have a build up of used equipment that has to be liquidat
componenttext: Could you just talk a little bit about how much of your revenues to dealers, particularly on the rental side are or even end users, are coming with tradings and, therefore, you would know maybe you have a build up of used equipment that has to be liquidated at some point?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know with one. What I would say is, if you look at U.S. in particular and extended downturn dating back to first quarter '06, I'd say used equipment fleets have been run down during that period of time. Because for the most of that duration, marke
componenttext: I don't know with one. What I would say is, if you look at U.S. in particular and extended downturn dating back to first quarter '06, I'd say used equipment fleets have been run down during that period of time. Because for the most of that duration, markets in the emerging markets were actually fairly good and say they've quite have used inventory that went abroad. So I'd say in addition to the rundown of the rental fleets, we've also seen a decline in used fleets as well. So we don't see anything in terms of really a build up of used equipment.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On rental, I kind of read off a few of the stats earlier, but rental utilization is up. I mean dealer in fleet size for rental is still very, very low. I mean, if you look at a graph of it, it looks like you can pick a sled down the hill and then just tak
componenttext: On rental, I kind of read off a few of the stats earlier, but rental utilization is up. I mean dealer in fleet size for rental is still very, very low. I mean, if you look at a graph of it, it looks like you can pick a sled down the hill and then just take a little tiny jump off the bottom. And ages have gone up dramatically over the past three or four years and remained elevated. So I think there's still a lot of work to do with rental fleets.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Jerry Revich. [Goldman Sachs]
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Jerry Revich. [Goldman Sachs]

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, you had excellent machine pricing this quarter particularly in North America. Can you step up through the drivers, and perhaps touch on why price increases had been lower and engines work capacity utilization in most of your markets is tighter?
componenttext: Mike, you had excellent machine pricing this quarter particularly in North America. Can you step up through the drivers, and perhaps touch on why price increases had been lower and engines work capacity utilization in most of your markets is tighter?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think one of the things with engines that's really changed in price realization, really, from the first half of the year is, last year, in the middle of the year, particularly on the bigger engines, despite the fact that it was a tough year, we di
componenttext: Well, I think one of the things with engines that's really changed in price realization, really, from the first half of the year is, last year, in the middle of the year, particularly on the bigger engines, despite the fact that it was a tough year, we did a mid-year price increase that we've lap that now. So it's in sort of the base period in comparison, if you will. So the machine price realization isn't maybe as high as it was earlier. In terms of machine price realization, I think honestly, we've been pleasantly surprised as we've gone through the year. As you know, we started out the year with an outlook of machine from price realization being up less than a point. Then at the end of the second quarter, we said about 1%, and it's been more than that all year long. Effectively, the merchandising programs require  to sell the product, I mean, of all kinds have been less than we thought. We've not taken any price increases per se. Generally, we do that most of the time just in January. Every once in a while, we do a midyear. We didn't do that this year. So I think just in general, we've been, I'd say, positively surprised on price all year long.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Doug, thinking about cycle over cycle a dealer inventories, the changes because of the Lane strategy, I guess, would we be off the market if we thought of 40% ship out of Lane 1 is translating to about a 30% reduction in dealer inventories versus prio
componenttext: And Doug, thinking about cycle over cycle a dealer inventories, the changes because of the Lane strategy, I guess, would we be off the market if we thought of 40% ship out of Lane 1 is translating to about a 30% reduction in dealer inventories versus prior cycles? Is that the type of  payout we should be thinking about?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jerry, I'm going to jump in on that. We are new at Lane this year, really, and I think that we need to get a little bit more history under our belt. And I think with dealer inventory, that will probably play out over the next year or so, as the program be
componenttext: Jerry, I'm going to jump in on that. We are new at Lane this year, really, and I think that we need to get a little bit more history under our belt. And I think with dealer inventory, that will probably play out over the next year or so, as the program becomes more mature. So probably about a year from now it'd be a better time to talk about that.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Mike just a quick follow-up, it looks like your dealer inventories are down about 40% from '07 when you had very similar sales levels for which you're going to have for machines in 2010. I guess just trying to understand the magnitude of inventory we
componenttext: And Mike just a quick follow-up, it looks like your dealer inventories are down about 40% from '07 when you had very similar sales levels for which you're going to have for machines in 2010. I guess just trying to understand the magnitude of inventory we stock, we should be thinking about any color you provide there would be helpful.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess I would say this, if you look at where we came off of '08, dealer inventory declined almost, not quite looks like close to 50% from the end of '08 to the end of '09, actually, the high-40s. And it's stayed pretty flat to this year. That was
componenttext: Well, I guess I would say this, if you look at where we came off of '08, dealer inventory declined almost, not quite looks like close to 50% from the end of '08 to the end of '09, actually, the high-40s. And it's stayed pretty flat to this year. That was a $3.5 billion inventory decline between '08 and '09. I can tell you that our approaching $50 billion next year does not have us back to '08 volume levels for kind of machine units. Remember, it has things like EMD in it, so it's not the same. Also, if you go back to the $51 billion that we had in '08, we only had Cat in Japan in for a quarter that year. So kind of the real underlying number with the companies that we have now was higher. So we're not back to that '08 level yet. We don't expect in this preliminary outlook this morning to be back to that '08 machine level in 2008 as yet. So not giving any numbers on dealer inventory, but I would certainly think that we're not going to be back to the '08 volumes, plus we have Lane so we're not looking for that magnitude of an increase.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Mike, I think the point that we can emphasize here, you look at like year-over-year, we're talking about an 84% growth in Machinery sales and we're talking about virtually flat dealer inventory. And that means that through working with our dealers, th
componenttext: And Mike, I think the point that we can emphasize here, you look at like year-over-year, we're talking about an 84% growth in Machinery sales and we're talking about virtually flat dealer inventory. And that means that through working with our dealers, the Lane strategy that we've been able to flow that increase directly into end users and of demand instead of having it set into inventory around the world. We're going to continue to partner with our dealers on how we do that going forward.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Robert Wertheimer. [Morgan Stanley]
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Robert Wertheimer. [Morgan Stanley]

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is on capacity and your comfort level with getting to next year's revenue guided range at the current capacity levels you've got. I mean, I guess last cycle as it worked out, you ended being short capacity and then try to add '06 to '08,
componenttext: My first question is on capacity and your comfort level with getting to next year's revenue guided range at the current capacity levels you've got. I mean, I guess last cycle as it worked out, you ended being short capacity and then try to add '06 to '08, I think you've comment at that time that you stop to order machine toward a longer time to get in. And so you ended up with some production issues that were capacity related. And I think, Doug, when you took over the range, you've ended up announcing a lot of capacity and I kind of wondered how much of that was just pure growth above that $50 billion level versus you weren't completely comfortable with the capacity, you had put in for most '06 to '08. So that's my first question whether you feel like you can get to the $50 billion with what you've got.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll start with that one. Capacity, unfortunately, is not fungible. It kind of depends upon what product your selling. If you look at big engines, for example, right now, out of Lafayette, it improved a lot since the depth of the recession. But as we talk
componenttext: I'll start with that one. Capacity, unfortunately, is not fungible. It kind of depends upon what product your selling. If you look at big engines, for example, right now, out of Lafayette, it improved a lot since the depth of the recession. But as we talked about earlier, and if you look in today's retail sales, oil and gas has flattened out. So for products like that, we probably have a lot more capacity than we would need for next year. For mining product, on the other hand, we'll be capacity constraint probably throughout 2011. I mean,  business there is very good to the point that you made earlier, we are investing in capacity increases. We talked about that for mining trucks in India and mining trucks in the U.S. We talked about investing in shovels, although that's not from a sales standpoint next year. So I think the answer is, we wouldn't have put out a guidance for next year approaching $50 billion and sort of a summary answer, we wouldn't have said that if we didn't think we can make it, number one; and number 2, how much capacity we have and how much more we can do, I think, it really depends a lot on what we're actually selling. There are a lot of products right now where volumes are still very depressed. You look at compact products, a very small stuff, it's improved, but still way off the peak. So we have a lot of capacity there. So just really depends a lot on the product. I know that sounds like a bit of a non-answer, but it's just not -- we're not like a refinery, it's not uniform capacity.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So is the debottlenecking you've gotten from adding some of the machine tools and adding some of the  capacity, I guess, I believe you can get the $50 billion. I guess, I wonder if you can get to it smoothly without the kind of strain you had in '07 and
componenttext:
So is the debottlenecking you've gotten from adding some of the machine tools and adding some of the  
capacity, I guess, I believe you can get the $50 billion. I guess, I wonder if you can get to it smoothly without the kind of strain you had in '07 and '08. And whether the debottlenecking more than offset the kind of increased depreciation and increased costs? And the second would be just in terms of people and capacity, I think your employment is around 10% down from peak. Is that enough to get you back to where you were giving improvements to the Production System?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one more comment on that. In terms of going from sort of middle of the middle of this years guidance $41.5 billion, something approaching $50 billion, the point that we made earlier, we're already -- our second half of the year is operating at around
componenttext: Just one more comment on that. In terms of going from sort of middle of the middle of this years guidance $41.5 billion, something approaching $50 billion, the point that we made earlier, we're already -- our second half of the year is operating at around $46 billion. We have amounts of capacity increases that should help next year. We talked about being able to produce more excavators in China, more mining product, for example, so some of the things that we did announce earlier this year should help next year and we are currently doing better than the full year average. So the -- as what's brought up earlier, the increase isn't maybe as dramatic as looking at $50 billion versus $41.5 billion. In terms of employment, even there, and again, I'm sorry if this sounds like a non-answer, but when you're looking at the production capability of employment, you got to look at not only our full times, we have a very large flexible workforce that we had actually going into the last downturn, which really allowed us to shed costs quickly. So you really have to add that to the employment number. There are also things like overtime that impact your kind of productive capacity out of people. So it in of itself is also not a perfect indicator. What I would tell you is, and we've said this a couple of times today, our labor productivity has improved a lot this year and that's been very good. We expected that from CPS and frankly, we would expect improvements to continue.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from David Raso. [ISI]
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from David Raso. [ISI]

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The question relates to '11 mining and also oil and gas. You mentioned a capacity constraint principally, I guess Decatur more than anywhere else. But thinking in the comment in the release about a 25% increase you've seen sequentially, 2Q to 3Q, is there
componenttext: The question relates to '11 mining and also oil and gas. You mentioned a capacity constraint principally, I guess Decatur more than anywhere else. But thinking in the comment in the release about a 25% increase you've seen sequentially, 2Q to 3Q, is there further delay exists now before India ramps up and so forth? Do we have much increase left to current capacity to increase sequentially? And if not, where is the current level of mining if we run this out through '11 on a year-over-year basis, '11 versus '10?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll try to answer as much of that as I can with what we're public with. Next year, we have invested and are investing in both Decatur in India. We do expect production levels for mining to be up next year. I would say that between the third and the
componenttext: Yes, I'll try to answer as much of that as I can with what we're public with. Next year, we have invested and are investing in both Decatur in India. We do expect production levels for mining to be up next year. I would say that between the third and the fourth quarter, we're kind of running up against this, so I don't think you'll see much dramatic change in mining between Q3 and Q4. If you look at our total top line, excluding EMD, in total top line, not mining specific, but it's not all that dissimilar than the third quarter and I would say mining probably fits in that boat.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just want to clear on the last comment, Mike, if I kept mining production today running out of the next four or five quarters, what is that year-over-year increase in mining '11 versus '10?
componenttext: Just want to clear on the last comment, Mike, if I kept mining production today running out of the next four or five quarters, what is that year-over-year increase in mining '11 versus '10?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We didn't give that. All I was really trying to say is I think the fourth quarter is probably not going to be dramatically different than the third quarter. That based on the improvements that we've put in place, the investments that we're making, we woul
componenttext: We didn't give that. All I was really trying to say is I think the fourth quarter is probably not going to be dramatically different than the third quarter. That based on the improvements that we've put in place, the investments that we're making, we would expect that production levels, as we go through next year, would improve.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on Solar, I just want to get a little update on how your seeing that order book develop for '11?
componenttext: And on Solar, I just want to get a little update on how your seeing that order book develop for '11?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we weren't specific at all with that in the release, but what I would call back to is, this year, for I think all of us as we got in the 2010, surprised a little on the upside. Solar took in some big orders very early in the year that helped them and
componenttext: Yes, we weren't specific at all with that in the release, but what I would call back to is, this year, for I think all of us as we got in the 2010, surprised a little on the upside. Solar took in some big orders very early in the year that helped them and those were from a couple of customers. And those they were able to do because they had capacity. Remember, they've been at capacity on the back of very strong oil and gas business for the last four years, and the last three have been records. So I wouldn't look for more increases in Solar or at least I wouldn't -- I'm being trying to be careful here because we haven't provided specific guidance on it. But yes, I wouldn't look for a big change in Solar up next year.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the customer advances are now 21% off the trough a few quarters ago back in 4Q '09, but often that is Solar, so just trying to square if your comment not expecting much growth in Solar in '11 versus customer advances, can you touch on that?
componenttext: On the customer advances are now 21% off the trough a few quarters ago back in 4Q '09, but often that is Solar, so just trying to square if your comment not expecting much growth in Solar in '11 versus customer advances, can you touch on that?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Customer advances would not just be Solar, but they're certainly a big piece of that. And again, we didn't provide any specific guidance this morning around Solar, so I'm just going to not push that one any further.
componenttext: Customer advances would not just be Solar, but they're certainly a big piece of that. And again, we didn't provide any specific guidance this morning around Solar, so I'm just going to not push that one any further.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And lastly, the geographic mix of where you see dealers need to increase there inventory, would you highlight any particular geographies where the dealers would like to and do you think you'll be able to serve it?
componenttext: And lastly, the geographic mix of where you see dealers need to increase there inventory, would you highlight any particular geographies where the dealers would like to and do you think you'll be able to serve it?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The second part of your question, in some ways, probably even more important part as we've been ramping up production. Where we have seen a little bit of inventory increase this year has been in Latin America and Asia, but again, it's been pretty small ev
componenttext: The second part of your question, in some ways, probably even more important part as we've been ramping up production. Where we have seen a little bit of inventory increase this year has been in Latin America and Asia, but again, it's been pretty small even there. And again, I think it's related to production, it's related to Lane strategy. I think probably truth be told, next year, if it plays out the way we think, dealers in all regions will probably want to add more. I think if you look at the historic averages, the months of supply are below in all regions today. So I think it'll be fairly pervasive.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Meredith Taylor. [Barclays Capital]
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Meredith Taylor. [Barclays Capital]

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll talk a little bit in broad trends, kind of things that we've already talked about. Electric power is probably doing, and industrial are probably doing the best of the four engine end markets. Then you can see from the retail sales today, the Marine h
componenttext: I'll talk a little bit in broad trends, kind of things that we've already talked about. Electric power is probably doing, and industrial are probably doing the best of the four engine end markets. Then you can see from the retail sales today, the Marine has very late cycle and that's going down. That will be probably a negative next year. Oil and gas is actually pretty flat, if memory serves me, I think it was around 1% over the last few months. So I think in engines, the trend that you're seeing is relative strength in electric power, industrial, late cycle weakness in marine, particularly the really big ocean going kind of marine, in a more neutral oil and gas kind of business. That's what the trend that you're seeing right now. In terms of machines, again, we didn't provide a lot of detail. I think probably most types of machines will be up next year. The parts of the business that are probably the least capacity constrained and the lowest in terms of how they're doing versus the last cycle would be the smaller equipment. So I think to some degree, there's probably the biggest scope for improvement there, they're very depressed as you can see in a lot of a residential and commercial construction markets, there's not a lot of business there right now. I know I wouldn't very helpful, probably with that answer, but again, we've not provided a lot of detail on the kind of the breakdown of 2011. It's a preliminary guidance, again, we're not trying to be overly cagey with it. We're still a few months from next year, we're still working on our plan and we don't normally provide a lot of detail at this time.

componenttextpreview: Meredith, this is Ed. Let me [[ph]] I mean in Lane 1, what we've seen, we kind of track service within 10 days and we've seen that jump about 20 points over the last quarter. And so we're seeing improved service out of Lane 1. Corporately in percent of sa
componenttext: Meredith, this is Ed. Let me [[ph]] I mean in Lane 1, what we've seen, we kind of track service within 10 days and we've seen that jump about 20 points over the last quarter. And so we're seeing improved service out of Lane 1. Corporately in percent of sales, about 25% coming out. In terms of Lane 1 inventory, we doubled it since the beginning of the year, and we are looking for additional Lane 1 inventory build as we get into the fourth quarter. And it's really focused on what we talked about earlier. We're looking at our -- what you saw across the U.S., Europe and Latin America and Asia, pretty strong year-over-year growth in the Machinery sales. But you're using Lane and working closer with our dealers, we've been able to flow that product through to the end-users. Instead of some of the things we had back in '07, '08 timeframe with a lot of it flowed into inventory. I think the Lane is continuing to mature, as Mike said we're relatively new at it, but I think some of the results are starting to bear fruit.

componenttext: Can we talk a little bit about profitability, particularly it's not hard to understand why machine profitability will step up at this point with a higher volume but it can sell their profitability to clean up the quarter. And so profitability hold these levels and engine profitability hold these levels with more sluggish kind of environment here particularly, not only this year but into next year or can we still improve operating profitability?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm probably going to disappoint you on this answer as well but again we can't talk about profitability much at all related to next year. Yet again, we're still -- if you look at what's implied for the fourth quarter, we have in the $3.90 we're $2.68 year
componenttext: I'm probably going to disappoint you on this answer as well but again we can't talk about profitability much at all related to next year. Yet again, we're still -- if you look at what's implied for the fourth quarter, we have in the $3.90 we're $2.68 year-to-date. So that would imply $1.22 or similar profit in the fourth quarter to what we had in the third quarter. And again, we've never really provided that separate guidance by product category. So I'll let you estimate what happened there.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can we talk about interim Tier 4 introduction, you haven't talked much about it. I guess, the pricings will be up more like 4%, but has not a lot of products you've introduced. Can you talk about the impact of what can we expect to see over the next year
componenttext: Can we talk about interim Tier 4 introduction, you haven't talked much about it. I guess, the pricings will be up more like 4%, but has not a lot of products you've introduced. Can you talk about the impact of what can we expect to see over the next year and the year after? What to expect with this emissions change being to flow in there, I guess is that with what the sales outside the U.S. is not all that big. Can you give us some indication of what we're going to impact in?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: For people listening on the call to, I'll make a comment. We do have a Q&A in the back of our release that talks a little bit more about Tier 4. But essentially, it's in the U.S. Tier 4, Europe Stage IIIB, it's for products for the most part in those regi
componenttext: For people listening on the call to, I'll make a comment. We do have a Q&A in the back of our release that talks a little bit more about Tier 4. But essentially, it's in the U.S. Tier 4, Europe Stage IIIB, it's for products for the most part in those regions above 165-horsepower this year, below 165-horsepower in 2012. So you're right, a lot of the product particularly the smaller products not going to be affected this year, it will be next year. From an engine standpoint, it would affect also product in those kind of size ranges in the U.S. and Europe, except for emergency power or backup power and emergency and backup power is most of what we do. So you're right to say that a lot of the product will be affected in the year and the larger product in the U.S., in Europe, but you won't see it all change on January 1. You have the ability to take some flex credits and delay some of the introductions. So I think it's probably going to be a little bit less of a giant January 1 shotgun start. It'll be more of a phase and I think as it go through the year. In either point, it doesn't affect all our service related businesses. It doesn't affect most of our engine business, it doesn't affect small machines, it doesn't affect Latin America or Asia or Middle East or the CIS. So it is probably a bit more of a muted impact from the total company than most people might think.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'd add to that is the other thing we haven't really seen much of is any significant type of pre-buy. Some of that's driven by the fact that the ability has moved out, as we've seen the strong increase in demand. I think the other factor th
componenttext: The only thing I'd add to that is the other thing we haven't really seen much of is any significant type of pre-buy. Some of that's driven by the fact that the ability has moved out, as we've seen the strong increase in demand. I think the other factor that's really out there is a certain degree especially in the U.S. of uncertainty amongst our customer base, we still don't have a highway bill. We still got uncertainty in terms of where we're going with tax legislation, and as you know a lot of these are small businesses. And so we really haven't had any, what I would consider, noticeable pre-buy on Tier 4 either.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. As you look for a leading indicators on new equipment demand, you look at rental fleet utilization, you look at used equipment prices. You can look at service parts business and actually all of those indicators right now look pret
componenttext: That's a great question. As you look for a leading indicators on new equipment demand, you look at rental fleet utilization, you look at used equipment prices. You can look at service parts business and actually all of those indicators right now look pretty positive. Again, we don't have a spare parts business per se. Parts are integral to each of our businesses, but certainly, demand has been very good this year. Used equipment prices have gone up and rental utilization has gone up. So that should actually be a very positive forward-looking group of indicators.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there anything you can share about how market shares in Asia, particularly China, have been trending, given all the focus on the region?
componenttext: Is there anything you can share about how market shares in Asia, particularly China, have been trending, given all the focus on the region?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say market share it is not something that we disclosed, so I won't be all that specific. But particularly in China, we've been capacity constraint and that's one of the reasons why we announced a fairly large capacity expansions. We're really
componenttext: Yes, I would say market share it is not something that we disclosed, so I won't be all that specific. But particularly in China, we've been capacity constraint and that's one of the reasons why we announced a fairly large capacity expansions. We're really starting in next year for China excavators because we think, if we can produce more, we can sell more. So I would say, particularly in that part of the business, we don't have the capacity all online yet so that will take a little bit more. Our business model is really based on field population, and field population is based on the strength of the industry and the share that we get. So it's a big deal to us to your point where we're really focused on it. Where we need to add capacity, we're trying to do that so yes, I'd say it's a big deal. But I won't quote numbers.

componenttext: I'm wondering if you can just comment, we haven't really talked about the 2012 goals that you've had for quite some time now, and I guess it just strikes me that things are going to have to accelerate from your preliminary 2011 guidance fairly markedly you'd still get a step into that 2012 level. I don't know if maybe if you wouldn't even agree with that, but are we still sticking with our 2012 goals? And we feel like this is fairly pro rata movement through the next couple of years or is there an uptick in 2012 that really gets us over that goal line?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Ed. I'd say our 2012 goals, as we laid out in the analyst meeting in New York recently, if you kind of think about the story that we laid out there, that be kind of laid a path that and said so we could get $55 billion in that 2012 timeline
componenttext: Steve, this is Ed. I'd say our 2012 goals, as we laid out in the analyst meeting in New York recently, if you kind of think about the story that we laid out there, that be kind of laid a path that and said so we could get $55 billion in that 2012 timeline. And I think the $50 billion, approaching $50 billion is a good step in that direction. And I think it really gets back to one of the earlier discussions some of the tailwinds that may be out there. While we have seen good growth in the developed parts of the world, as you know, they are still way off, the peaks. We talked earlier about rental inventory being down, dealer inventory being well below historical levels, engine business kind of a later cycle hasn't really started to pickup recently. So as I look out to that 2012 timeline and the goal that we established, I think there's still the underlying principles and fundamentals are still there.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess that's a good one to conclude and I'll end it on that but that is exactly right. We went over with everyone in some detail in August, 2012 numbers and how we constructed the  path to get there. That's still our plan. We're still expecting that on
componenttext:
I guess that's a good one to conclude and I'll end it on that but that is exactly right. We went over with everyone in some detail in August, 2012 numbers and how we constructed the  path to get there. That's still our plan. We're still expecting that on our and beyond and as we talked in August, there's no change to that. If you look at the economic GDP growth next year, which is anemic worldwide, and maybe a little bit more anemic than we said in August, I view that as upside because the world cannot grow very long with these low rates, it's just uncunable, something will happen at some point and it will go and pickup and that's ahead of us in terms of their tailwind. But we are absolutely still on the ballpark from what we said in August.
And just while I've got the floor, I'm going to may be just comment a bit. Ed Rapp, of course is our new CFO in the executive office, and he's doing a great job. You may not see me on everyone of these calls because he and Mike are doing so well, so before I get too proud of them, I'll stop because I don't want to be. Ed, certainly can handle it and is doing great and is a great representative for us. And he and Mike is doing a super job, so you would expect to see them at some calls on the quarterlies in the future. And we thank you all for joining us today. Mike?
